title: Isolate
text: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.
speech: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.
pacedSpeech: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.

title: Subtraction Property of Inequality
text: To isolate the variable, we can subtract 8u from both sides of the inequality. This gives us $$5u-8u \leq 8u-21-8u$$.
speech: To isolate the variable, we can subtract 8u from both sides of the inequality. This gives us  5 u minus 8 u is less than or equal to 8 u minus 21 minus 8 u .
pacedSpeech: To isolate the variable, we can subtract 8u from both sides of the inequality. This gives us   5 u minus 8 u is less than or equal to 8 u minus 21 minus 8 u

title: Simplify
speech: Simplifying the inequality gives us  minus 3 u is less than or equal to, negative 21 .
pacedSpeech: Simplifying the inequality gives us   minus 3 u is less than or equal to, negative 21

title: Division Property of Inequality
text: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by $$-3$$, which gives us u on the left hand side and $$7$$ on the right hand side.
speech: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by  minus 3 , which gives us u on the left hand side and  7  on the right hand side.
pacedSpeech: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by   minus 3
, which gives us u on the left hand side and   7

title: Inequality Sign
text: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have $$v \geq 7$$.
speech: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have , v is greater than or equal to 7 .
pacedSpeech: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have  , v is greater than or equal to 7

title: Interval Notation: Parentheses and Brackets
text: In interval notation, brackets are used when the left or right sides of the interval are included in the solution. For example, the expression $$"x \leq -1"$$ includes all numbers less than or equal to $$-1$$. Since $$-1$$ is included in the solution, the interval notation is $$(-\infty,-1]$$. Since $$\infty$$ represents "infinity" and is not an actual number, we always put a parenthesis next to $$\infty$$.
speech: In interval notation, brackets are used when the left or right sides of the interval are included in the solution. For example, the expression  quotation mark x is less than or equal to negative 1 quotation mark,  includes all numbers less than or equal to  negative 1 . Since  negative 1  is included in the solution, the interval notation is , the open closed interval from negative infinity to negative 1 . Since  infinity  represents "infinity" and is not an actual number, we always put a parenthesis next to  infinity .
